pages.title: Mechanical Stress
pages.text: $(thing)Stress/$ (also known as $(thing)su/$) is the unit used for measuring mechanical power. $(thing)Stress/$ capacity can be generated by several methods which can be explored $(bold)$(l:getting_started/power)here/$.$(br2)$(thing)Stress/$ is consumed by various $(bold)$(l:getting_started/devices)Mechanical Devices/$ connected to a mechanical system. The amount consumed is based on both the device itself, and the $(thing)RPM/$ it is operating at.

By using the $(bold)$(l:tools/goggles)Engineer's Goggles/$, you can see the $(thing)Stress/$ capacity generated by a power source, as well as the $(thing)Stress/$ requirement of an attached device.$(br2)The goggles also allow you to see the exact $(thing)Stress/$ requirement of various items in their tooltips instead of the basic low/medium/high that displays otherwise.

pages.title: Measuring Stress
pages.text: While the $(bold)$(l:tools/goggles)Engineer's Goggles/$ allow you to see the $(thing)Stress/$ of individual components, the $(item)Stressometer/$, when combined with the engineer's goggles, let you see the $(thing)Stress/$ capacity and consumption of an entire system.$(br2)The $(item)Speedometer/$ can be used in a similar way to see the speed a shaft is rotating.
